variant.question: A student pilot has just learnt that meteorological information for aircraft en route on long-haul flights is sent by radio. What kind of radio receiver is needed to receive this information?

options.text: Single sideband receiver.
VHF receiver.
LF/MF receiver.
Double sideband receiver.

variant.question: Which of the following is most likely affected by fading during the twilight period?

options.text: MF
UHF
HF
VHF

variant.question: Which of the following is most likely affected by fading during the twilight period?

options.text: MF
UHF
HF
WHF

variant.question: Which physical phenomenon is the main reasons for the Mountain Effect?

options.text: Reflection
Damping
Scattering
Interference

variant.question: A pilot departs an aerodrome on the West coast of Spain at dawn for a flight to New York. Half an hour after departure, the VHF station for communication can no longer be received. What are two of the main reasons that VHF radio range is limited to line of sight?

options.text: No reflection by the ionosphere, and no surface wave.
Absorption by the ionosphere, and no direct waves.
Inversion of polarisation by the ionosphere, and attenuation.
Fading by reflected signals, and limited transmission power.

variant.question: With a Doppler VOR system and frequency decreasing:

options.text: the transmitter is moving away
the transmitter is moving to the receiver
the transmitter and receiver are stationary
the transmitter and the receiver are moving closer

variant.question: What kind of disturbances may occur in the area marked by the circle in the figure?

options.text: Fading and interference
Diffraction
Shoreline/Coastal effect
Absorption

variant.question: With regard to types of transmission, which of the following statements is true:

options.text: Continuous Wave transmission can be either frequency or amplitude modulated.
Pulse transmission is suitable only for NDB's.
In pulse transmission the frequency is modulated to facilitate range measurement.
Continuous Wave transmission varies only in amplitude.

variant.question: With regard to types of transmission, which of the following statements is true:

options.text: Continuous Wave transmission can be either frequency or amplitude modulated
In pulse transmission the frequency is modulated to facilitate range measurement
Pulse transmission is suitable only for NDBs
Continuous Wave transmission varies only in amplitude

variant.question: You are trying to get a bearing on an NDB in the MF frequency range. In theory, how can you best receive a strong enough signal?

options.text: Climb to increase your chance of capturing the sky wave.
Fly towards the NDB to better capture the sky wave.
Increase your distance from the NDB to better capture the ground wave.
Climb to increase your chance of capturing the ground wave.

variant.question: A radio signal is used to establish voice communications between the ground and an aircraft. This signal is transmitted in A3E. The number 3 means that the:

options.text: carrier is modulated by an analogue signal
emitter transmits the complete carrier and the two sidebands
emitter transmits the half carrier and only one of the two sidebands
carrier is modulated by a digital information

variant.question: Which of the following errors affects the use of VOR?

options.text: Scalloping
Quadrantal error
Night effect
Coastal refraction

variant.question: A flight crew is preparing for a VOR approach to their destination airport which contains a procedure turn involving a 80° left turn. This procedure turn consists of a straight segment with track guidance, followed by a 80° left turn. The next step will be a...

options.text: 260° turn to intercept the inbound track.
timed straight segment without track guidance and a 180° left turn to intercept the inbound track.
timed straight segment without track guidance and a 180° right turn to intercept the inbound track.
timed left turn to intercept the inbound track.

variant.question: Which of the following statements regarding the DME range is correct?

options.text: The range of DME is line of sight.
The DME operates on the principle of phase comparison.
The DME operates on VHF.
The DME has unlimited range due to ground wave propagation.

variant.question: A DME ground station can generally respond to a maximum of 100 aircraft at once. What is the reason for this limitation?

options.text: Saturation of the DME ground station working on only one receive frequency and one transmit frequency.
Saturation of the DME receivers in the aircraft, receiving all interrogations of other aircraft in the vicinity that are on the same frequency.
The difference in strengths of the received signals CANNOT be differentiated by the DME ground station, and consequently the weakest signals fall off.
Limitation of transmission by the echo protection circuit, which avoids replies being reflected and coming back into the DME ground station.

variant.question: With respect to the monitoring system of a VOR which statement is correct?

options.text: failure of the VOR station to stay within the required limits can cause the removal of identification and navigation components from the carrier or radiation to cease
failure of the VOR station to stay within the required limits will trigger a VOR caution annunciator in the cockpit.
the system monitors directly the phase of the reference signal and the phase of the variable signal.
if the monitoring system detects a change in the measured radial the transmission power will be reduced and consequently only aircraft in the terminal area can use the VOR.

variant.question: With respect to the monitoring system of a VOR which statement is correct?

options.text: failure of the VOR station to stay within the required limits can cause the removal of identification and navigation components from the carrier or radiation to cease.
failure of the VOR station to stay within the required limits will trigger a VOR caution annunciator in the cockpit.
if the monitoring system detects a change in the measured radial the transmission power will be reduced and consequently only aircraft in the terminal area can use the VOR.
the system monitors directly the phase of the reference signal and the phase of the variable signal.

variant.question: Which of the following is correct regarding false beams on a glide path?

options.text: False beams will only be found above the correct glide path.
False beams are only present when flying a back-beam ILS approach.
False beams will only be found more than 10 degrees to the left or to the right of the localiser centreline.
False beams will only be found below the correct glide path.

variant.question: You are flying along an airway in Northern Canada and you wish to check the position calculated by the IRS by taking a bearing from a nearby VOR. You tune to Churchill VOR and you find that you are flying on radial 190°. What is the true bearing to be plotted on a chart if the variation at the VOR is 2°W and at the aircraft is 2°E?

Which of the following correctly describes the principle of operation of Distance Measuring Equipment (DME)?
  1. The aircraft's primary radar system transmits a signal that triggers a reply from the DME station.
  2. A transmission from the aircraft's interrogator triggers a reply from the DME station.
  3. The time taken from interrogation transmission to the reply reception is used to determine slant range.
  4. The time taken from interrogation transmission to the reply reception is used to determine plan range.

options.text: 2 and 3
2 and 4
1 and 2
3 and 4

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the mountain effect as regards radio wave propagation?

options.text: It can be caused by diffraction of an NDB signal bending the path of the radio waves.
It prevents an aircraft at low altitude receiving VOR signals due to mountains blocking the radio waves.
It can be caused by refraction of a VOR signal bending the path of the radio waves.
It can be caused by refraction of an NDB signal changing the path of the radio waves.

variant.question: With regard to the range of NDBs and the accuracy of the bearings they provide can be stated that in general at night:

options.text: The range increases and the accuracy decreases
The range decreases and the accuracy increases
The range and the accuracy both increase
The range and the accuracy both decrease

variant.question: Which statement is correct with respect to the range of an NDB?

options.text: With propagation over sea the range will be greater than the range with propagation over land.
In order to double the range of an NDB, the transmission power should be increased with a factor 16.
The range depends on the altitude of the aircraft.
During the night the range of an NDB will decrease due to the interference of the direct- and earth reflected wave.

variant.question: Which of the following correctly describes the Instrument Landing System (ILS) localiser radiation pattern?

options.text: Two overlapping lobes on the same VHF carrier frequency.
Two overlapping lobes on the same UHF carrier frequency.
A pencil beam comprising a series of smaller beams each carrying a different modulation.
Two overlapping lobes on different radio carrier frequencies but with the same modulation.

variant.question: Which of the following correctly describes the Instrument Landing System (ILS) localiser radiation pattern?

options.text: Two overlapping lobes on the same VHF carrier frequency
Two overlapping lobes on the same UHF carrier frequency
A pencil beam comprising a series of smaller beams each carrying a different modulation
Two overlapping lobes on different radio carrier frequencies but with the same modulation

variant.question: Which of these options correctly describes the basic principles of operation of an MLS?

options.text: The time interval between the TO and FROM scans in Azimuth and elevation determines the aircraft position within the coverage area.
Guidance is given using the localiser and the glide path selected by the pilot, the guidance is based on the received and measured difference in depth of modulation (DDM).
Guidance is provided based on the pilots’ selection of the transmitters providing the pilot with the required localiser and glide path.
The distance between the TO and FROM scans in azimuth and elevation determines the aircraft position, within the coverage area.

variant.question: You are disobeying international restrictions and making an ILS approach in Russia. The DME indicates 2.5 NM and you are at a height of 1 000 m. What is your ground distance from the runway?

You are making an approach to Daytona Beach runway 25 which has a published back-course approach. Which of the following statements is correct with respect to localiser indications on an omni-bearing indicator (OBI) and a horizontal situation indicator (HSI)?

options.text: Reverse sensing will always occur on the OBI regardless of the course set; the HSI will sense correctly with the front-course set.
The OBI will sense correctly with the front-course set. The HSI will sense correctly with the back-course set.
The OBI will sense correctly with the front-course set. The HSI will sense correctly with the front-course set.
Reverse sensing will always occur on the OBI regardless of the course set; the HSI will sense correctly with the back-course set.

variant.question: Which one of the following is an advantage of a Microwave Landing System (MLS) compared with an Instrument Landing System (ILS)?

options.text: It is insensitive to geographical site and can be installed at sites where it is not possible to use an ILS
There is no restriction on the number of ground installations that can be operated because there is an unlimited number of frequency channels available
The installation does not require to have a separate method (marker beacons or DME) to determine range
It does not require a separate azimuth (localiser) and elevation (azimuth) transmitter

variant.question: Which one of the following is an advantage of a Microwave Landing System (MLS) compared with an Instrument Landing System (ILS)?

options.text: It is insensitive to geographical site and can be installed at sites where it is not possible to use an ILS
It does not require a separate azimuth -localiser- and elevation -azimuth- transmitter
There is no restriction on the number of ground installations that can be operated because there is an unlimited number of frequency channels available
The installation does not require to have a separate method -marker beacons or DME- to determine range

variant.question: Which one of the following is an advantage of a Microwave Landing System (MLS) compared with an Instrument Landing System (ILS)?

options.text: It is insensitive to geographical site and can be installed at sites where it is not possible to use an ILS.
The installation does not require to have a separate method (marker beacons or DME) to determine range.
It does not require a separate azimuth (localiser) and elevation (azimuth) transmitter.
There is no restriction on the number of ground installations that can be operated because there is an unlimited number of frequency channels available.

variant.question:
A locator:
1. Is a low powered beacon  
2. Is a high powered beacon  
3. Has a range of 10 -25NM  
4. Has a range of 10 -200NM

options.text: 1 and 3
2 and 4
2 and 3
1 and 4

variant.question: Which of the following options states the correct frequency band, propagation path and frequency range for an NDB?

options.text: LF and MF, surface waves, 190 KHz to 1750 KHz.
MF only, surface waves, 300 KHz to 1750 KHz.
UHF only, space waves, 329.15 MHz to 335 MHz
VHF only, ground waves, 108 MHz to 117.975 MHz.

variant.question:
A TACAN has a frequency of 109.0 MHz given amongst other frequencies 
Assuming the TACAN is serviceable, the aircraft is within range and the transmission have been correctly timed, identified, and verified, the information available by setting 109.0 MHz in the VHF Nav radio control panel or box is?

options.text: Slant range from the transmitter
Magnetic bearing and plan range from the transmitter
Magnetic bearing and slant range from the transmitter
Nothing as TACAN is military equipment

variant.question: You are flying in northern Canada along airway NCA Whiskey and you wish to check the position calculated by the IRS by taking a bearing from a nearby VOR. You tune to Churchill VOR and you find that you are flying on radial 300°. What is the bearing to be plotted on a chart if the variation at the VOR is 2°W and variation at the aircraft is 4°E.

Figure B
Figure C

options.text: Figure D
Figure C
Figure B

variant.question: You are on a magnetic heading of 055° and your ADF indicates a relative bearing of 325°. The QDM is:
Which of the following is the ICAO allocated frequency band for ADF receivers?

A VOR and an NDB are co-located. An aircraft equipped with an RMI is flying away from the beacons on a radial of 090º through an area where magnetic variation is changing rapidly. Which statement is correct?

options.text: The ADF needle moves, the VOR needle does not.
Both VOR and ADF needles move.
Neither the VOR or the NDB needles move.
The VOR needle moves, the ADF needle does not.

variant.question:
(For this question use annex 062-306-2008)
 You are flying over sea parallel to the coastline. An NDB is situated 10 NM inland. In which of the sectors in the image below does the shoreline/coastal effect reach its minimum?

options.text: Sectors A + B
In all sectors the same strength
Sectors C + D
Sectors A + D

variant.question: A multimode receiver which can receive ILS, MLS and GBAS inputs is fitted to an aircraft.The advantage of this type of receiver is that it...

options.text: reduces training requirements.
allows an approach to be flown using inputs from all three systems.
is more accurate.
automatically identifies and connects to nearby radio aids.

variant.question: You are about to pass overhead a DME station at FL300 with an true ground speed of 300 kt.What would your DME instrument read?

options.text: Ground speed less than 300 kt and 5 DME
Ground speed 300 kt and 5 DME
Ground speed 300 kt and 7 DME
Ground speed less than 300 kt and 7 DME

variant.question: A pilot flying an ILS approach with the "Marker" selected on the intercom hears a steady sequence of dots. What is the colour of the cockpit indicator that is associated with this audio signal?

options.text: white.
green.
blue.
amber.

variant.question: A VDF may be used...

options.text: to provide the ATC controller with bearings of aircraft in the absence of radar.
in emergency type situations when the aircraft is unable to transmit on VHF.
in combination with radar to solve the 180 ambiguity.
in lieu of ILS for precision approach purposes.

variant.question: Which statement about the errors and effects on NDB radio signals is correct?

options.text: The mountain effect is caused by reflections onto steep slopes of mountainous terrain which may cause big errors in the bearing.
Lightning during atmospheric disturbances may cause a reduction of the signal strength that may result in only slight bearing errors.
Night effect is a result of interference of the surface wave and the space wave causing a reduction in range.
Shoreline effects may cause a huge bearing error due to reflection of the radio signal onto steep coasts.

variant.question: A cumulonimbus cloud in the vicinity of an aeroplane can cause certain navigation systems to give false indications. This is particularly applies to the..

options.text: ADF.
weather radar.
VOR.
DME.

variant.question: Which one of the statements below is correct regarding the DME?

options.text: The DME operating frequencies are in the UHF frequency band.
Two lines of position obtained from two different DME's give an unambiguous fix.
The indicated distance is the ground distance measured from the aircraft's projected position on the ground to the DME ground installation.
The DME ground station is always co-located with a VOR station.

variant.question: Which one of the following correctly lists the major ground based components of a Microwave Landing System (MLS)?

options.text: Separate azimuth and elevation transmitters, DME facility
Combined azimuth and elevation transmitter, DME facility
Combined azimuth and elevation transmitter, outer and inner marker beacons
Separate azimuth and elevation transmitters, outer and middle marker beacons

variant.question: A VOR and DME are co-located. You want to identify the DME by listening to the callsign. Having heard the same callsign 4 times in 40 seconds the:

options.text: DME callsign is the one with the higher pitch that was broadcast only once
DME callsign is the one with the lower pitch that was broadcast several times
VOR and DME callsigns were the same and broadcast with the same pitch
DME callsign was not transmitted, the distance information is sufficient proof of correct operation

variant.question: Your RBI is indicating a relative bearing of 270° to an NDB. Your magnetic heading is 176°. You have tuned in a VOR, which is co-located with the NDB. If your OBI is set to 056°, what will it indicate?

options.text: Full scale deflection to the right, TO indication.
Half scale deflection to the right, FROM indicattion.
Half scale deflection to the left, FROM indication.
Full scale deflection to the left, TO indication.

variant.question: You are approaching a DME station during a flight in Russia. The DME indication is 1.5 NM and your height is 1 000 m. What is your ground distance to the station? (your result may differ slightly, please choose the closest value)
A VOR and DME are co-located. During an ident cycle of 40 seconds, four call sign transmissions are received.The DME call sign is...

options.text: the one with the higher pitch that was broadcast only once.
the one with the lower pitch that was broadcast more than once.
not transmitted as the distance information is sufficient proof of correct operation.
the same as the VOR’s and broadcast with the same pitch.

variant.question: While flying an ILS approach you notice that the localiser needle is at half scale deflection. Can the approach be continued?

options.text: Yes, as long as the glide-slope is within half scale deflection
No, a missed approach must be performed once the localiser display goes outside a quarter scale deflection
Yes, the approach can be continued under any circumstances
No, a missed approach must be performed as obstacle clearance is no longer guaranteed

variant.question: Which one of the following methods is used by a Microwave Landing System (MLS) to indicate distance from the runway threshold?

options.text: Measurement of range by a precision facility DME frequency paired with the azimuth and elevation channels.
Measurement of the frequency shift between the MLS azimuth and elevation transmissions
Timing the interval between the reception of sequential secondary radar pulses from the MLS station to the aircraft
Timing the interval between the transmission and reception of primary radar pulses from the aircraft to MLS station

variant.question: Which one of the following methods is used by a Microwave Landing System (MLS) to indicate distance from the runway threshold?

options.text: A precision facility DME
Measurement of the frequency shift between the MLS azimuth and elevation transmissions
Timing the interval between the transmission and reception of primary radar pulses from the aircraft to MLS station
Timing the interval between the reception of sequential secondary radar pulses from the MLS station to the aircraft

variant.question: Which one of the following methods is used by a Microwave Landing System (MLS) to indicate distance from the runway threshold?

options.text: A precision facility DME.
Measurement of the frequency shift between the MLS azimuth and elevation transmissions.
Timing the interval between the reception of sequential secondary radar pulses from the MLS station to the aircraft.
Timing the interval between the transmission and reception of primary radar pulses from the aircraft to MLS station.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the variable, or directional, signal of a conventional VOR is correct?

options.text: The rotation of the variable signal at a rate of 30 times per second gives it the characteristics of a 30 Hz amplitude modulation.
The transmitter changes the frequency of the variable signal by 30 Hz either side of the allocated frequency each time it rotates.
The receiver adds 30 Hz to the variable signal before combining it with the reference signal.
The transmitter varies the amplitude of the variable signal by 30 Hz each time it rotates.

variant.question: You are flying parallel to the coastline (see diagram below). An NDB is positioned about 10 NM inland. In which areas will you observe the shoreline/coastal effect?

options.text: Area C+D, deflection to the coastline
Area A+B, deflection seawards
Area C+D, deflection seawards
Area A+B, deflection to the coastline

variant.question: A pilot flying an aircraft at FL 80, tunes in a VOR which has an elevation of 313 m. Given ISA conditions, what is the maximum theoretical distance at which a pilot might expect to receive the VOR signals?

options.text: 151 NM
180 NM
100 NM
120 NM

variant.question: A radio beacon has an operational range of 10 NM. By what factor should the transmitter power be increased in order to achieve an operational range of 20 NM?

options.text: Four
Two
Six
Eight

variant.question: A DVOR is less sensitive to site errors than a CVOR because..

options.text: the variable phase is frequency modulated rather than amplitude modulated.
of the presence of a monitoring system.
of the smaller VOR antenna.
of the use of vertical polarised waves instead of horizontal polarised waves.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about the MLS is true?

options.text: It operates in the VHF band and the frequency allocation is between 108.1 to 111.95 MHz.
It operates on one of 40 channels in the band 329.15 to 335 MHz (UHF).
It operates on one of 200 channels in the band 5.03 GHz to 5.09 GHz (SHF).
It operates on one of 126 channels within an allocated frequency spread of 960 to 1 215 MHz (UHF).

variant.question: A pilot is flying an ILS approach. What indication will there be on the HSI if the aircraft is on a false glide path?

options.text: No visual indication
A red light on the Primary Flight Display (PFD)
A glide path red flag.
An aural warning

variant.question: Which of the following is true for NDB frequency bands?

options.text: Transmits in LF or MF bands (190 kHz - 1 750 kHz, ground waves).
Transmits only in VHF bands (108 MHz - 117.975 MHz, direct waves).
Transmits only in UHF bands (329.15 MHz - 335 MHz, direct waves).
Only transmits in MF bands (300 kHz - 1 750 kHz, ground waves).

variant.question: Which of the following is the ICAO allocated frequency band for aeronautical NDBs?

options.text: 190 kHz to 1750 kHz
200 kHz to 2000 kHz
255 kHz to 455 kHz
300 kHz to 3000 kHz

variant.question: A VOR is sited at position 58°00'N 073°00'W where the magnetic variation equals 32°W. An aircraft is located at position 56°00'N 073°00'W where the magnetic variation equals 28°W. The aircraft is on VOR radial:
A VOR/DME Area Navigation system will revert to dead reckoning mode if information is received from

options.text: only one VOR.
one VOR and two DMEs.
one VOR and one DME.
two DMEs.

A DME is located at MSL

7 NM

variant.question: Would an MLS facility be useless if the DME is unserviceable?

options.text: No, it can be used for straight in approaches like ILS but without distance information.
Yes, because both facilities are frequency paired.
No, it can still be used for MLS approaches but without distance indications in the cockpit.
Yes, an MLS facility uses an integrated DME system and if the DME fails, the MLS also fails.

options.text: made audible via the audio control panel in NAV
made visible through the three flashing marker lights
decoded in text, showing the frequency and runway number
shown on the related ILS localiser display

variant.question: Which statement is correct for homing towards an NDB in an area with constant wind and constant magnetic variation?

options.text: The Relative Bearing of the NDB should be kept 000°.
The Relative Bearing of the NDB should be equal (in magnitude and sign) to the applied Wind Correction Angle.
The Relative Bearing of the NDB should be equal to the QDM.

variant.question: Which of the following options can be used for entry into a holding pattern based on a VOR/DME fix?

options.text: The DME arc defining the fix.
Tracking to the VOR.
The entry radial to the start of the inbound leg.
Any track into the VOR/DME fix.

options.text: approximately a quarter of the scale.
the outer dot.
approximately halfway the scale.
approximately three quarters of the scale.

options.text: Approximately a quarter of the scale.

It is pilot interpreted and does not require the assistance of ATC

options.text: DME Morse ident is the one with the higher pitch that was broadcast only once.
VOR and DME Morse idents were the same and broadcast with the same pitch.

Which of the following statements is correct regarding the Night Effect?

options.text: At night the ionosphere’s D-layer is insignificant and Low Frequency (LF) / Medium Frequency (MF) signals are returned by the E- and F-layers.
At night the ionosphere’s E- and F-layers are insignificant and Very Low Frequency (VLF) / Very High Frequency (VHF) signals are returned by the D-layer.

At night the ionosphere’s F-layer is insignificant and Very Low Frequency(VLF) / Very High Frequency (VHF) signals are returned by the D- and E-layers.

variant.question: Which statement is correct according to ICAO DOC 8168?

The pilot has to fly the ILS GP to a maximum of 0.14° fly up deflection of the GP in order to stay in protected airspace.

variant.question: Which statement is correct according to ICAO DOC 8168?

options.text: The aircraft has to be established within half scale deflection of the LLZ before starting descent on the GP.
The pilot has to fly the ILS GP to a maximum of 1/5 fly up deflection of the GP in order to stay in protected airspace.

The accuracy the pilot has to fly the ILS LLZ to be considered established on an ILS track is within ¼ scale deflection of the required track.

The aircraft altitude can increase.

Both the direction of the ADF pointer and the direction of the VOR pointer will change.
Neither the direction of the ADF pointer nor the direction of the VOR pointer will change.
